If the user provides any Special Instructions, prioritize them over the above guidelines.

# Task

You are given a DataFrame `df_cars` with car data with columns `manufacturer` and `model`. Write a function audi_filter that filters down the dataset to only the rows with manufacturer “audi” and model being “a4 or “a4 quattro”, then it should create a new column `audi_a4_type` that equals `true` across all rows. Then return the resulting DataFrame.



# Special Instructions

None.

In Julia, you can use broadcasting to simplify tasks like this, which makes it more readable and efficient than traditional loops or functions. Here is a solution for your problem:

```julia
using DataFrames

function audi_filter(df::DataFrame)
    # Filter down the dataset to only rows with manufacturer "audi" and model being "a4 or "a4 quattro"
    df = filter(row -> row.manufacturer == "audi", df)
    df = filter(row -> row.model == "a4" || row.model == "a4 quattro", df)

    # Create a new column `audi_a4_type` that equals true across all rows
    df[:audi_a4_type] = [true for _ in 1:nrow(df)]
    
    return df
end
```

This function first filters down the DataFrame to only include rows where manufacturer is "audi" and model is either "a4" or "a4 quattro". It then adds a new column `audi_a4_type` that equals true for all of these rows.

You can test this function with some example data:

```julia
# Sample DataFrame
df = DataFrame(manufacturer=["toyota", "ford", "audi", "audi"], model=["corolla", "fiesta", "a4", "a4 quattro"])

# Call the function
new_df = audi_filter(df)
```

This will return a new DataFrame that includes only rows where manufacturer is "audi" and model is either "a4" or "a4 quattro". The `audi_a4_type` column will also be included, all of which equal true.
